### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n>Output:		Authoritarian

He didn’t remember the street name and found a map with streets with very similar names running parallel to his destination. He needed to travel up to 20 blocks from his present position. Choices: 1:  A: Look up the street names of all possible streets and check them one by one  B: Ask a policeman at a crossroad  C: Stop any car and ask the occupants  D: Look up the street name in the map and take the first possible street.<n>Output: D<n><n>Input:A young lady in a village is taking care of 5 horses. One day, she went to the market to buy salt. On the way, she bought a pound of green beans and a pound of peas. Unfortunately, because of the rain she did not take a bucket, so she decided to carry everything in a sack. When she came back home, she realized that she was carrying the sack upside down. When she turned it upright, the peas fell out on the road, while the green beans fell into a crack among the stones in the path. The only thing she could do was step on the crack to push the green beans down into the sack, thus making room for the peas to fall in. On the way to the market, she did not pass any stores, so she could not exchange anything. When she got back, she used the rest of the salt in her kitchen and did not have salt enough for her horses. What would be the maximum weight in pounds that the peas could have weighed?<n>Output: 2<n><n>Input:In a square, there are 5 numbers which sum up to 100, the range of each number in the square is 9-12<n>Output: 100<n><n>Input:In order to avoid getting any wrong answers on a math test. Make sure that you're using Eclipse as your IDE program.<n><n>Please do not include any other format (such as.txt) on your submission.<n><n>Each answer is worth points which will be indicated on a Score Report.<n><n>You have 2 attempts at completing the program. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:What do drugs do? Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n>Output:		A<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>#### Part1 input:The difference in ages between Richard Hurley is age 20. if Hurley is 10 years old what there combined ages 40?<n><n>    for cnt in range(10):                               # loop number is ten<n>        if(Hurly Age<20-cnt):                           # if Hurly Age is < 20- the total<n>            Hurly Age<n>            print(Hurly+Rich, "years old")                      <n>        elif(Hurly Age>20-cnt):<n>            Hurley Age-20+20-cnt<n>            print(Hurrly+Rich, " years old")<n>            break                      <n>    print(Hurly,Rich, " years old 40 years from")                   # HUlly 14, Richard is 36<n>            <n>#### Part2 input: Pablo’s mother agreed to pay him one cent to every page he reads.  <n><n>    cnt = 0;<n>    pages=0<n><n>    while True:<n>        page = int(input("Please input how many pages you read: "))<n><n>        ifpage <= 0: <n>            break<n>    <n>        page -= cnt              # ifpage is not equal zero, page - cnt is 1, cnt is 0 - 1<n>        cnt += 1           # cnt is 1 bigger<n>        pages+=1<n><n>        ifpage%150 == 0 :<n>            cnt = 0  # ifpage is 150, cnt is zero<n><n>#      ifpage, print("reading",pages, cnt)<n>            break               # end of loop, print pages<n>            <n>### End of Instructions<n><n>### Solutions input of Instruction:<n><n>    Part 1 input<n>    <n>    Hurly age<n>    Please input Hurly Age: 10<n>    Please input Hurlie Aget: 12<n>    <n>    Hurle 12  Years old 40 Years from<n><n>    Part 2 input<n>    <n>    cnt =10<n>    cnt =0<n>    pages=0 <n>    <n>    Please input how many pages you did read: 1080<n>    Please input how

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Where would you see people in uniform playing with a ball? Choices:  A: hole B: television C: sporting goods store D: pool table E: sporting event<n>Output:		C<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>My explanation for how to do this is very simple. I’ll try my best to make it understandable. Let us first look into the first question.<n><n>Suppose Hurley is now 14. Now, it’s the time for Richard to be 14 as well. Therefore, Hurley + Richard = 14 + 14 = 28.<n><n>As we can see, age is calculated by subtraction. If we keep increasing Hurley by 20 years from now, then the answer will be 128.<n><n>Now, the next question. Suppose we had 150 pages in a book and Pablo plan to read every single page of the book. As we know, adding 150 with 150 can give us 300. Therefore, Pablo read for 300 pages after buying one cent for every single page he reads.<n><n>Therefore, the answer is c.<n><n>Next, let us look into a second question.<n><n>Supposed Pablo had $3 left over from his allowance to buy candy. How much is the original amount of book that Pablo bought?<n><n>Let take a look at the equation.<n><n>1 book x $1700 will give us $1700<n><n>Total amount of candy + $3 = $15<n><n>Total amount of one book = $3 +$15= $18<n><n><n><n>### Code for Question#2<n><n><img src="https://i.postimg.cc/2G7JZ4xY/Screen-Shot-2019-12-27-at-1.17.46-AM.png" alt="uploading code" style="width: 800px; height: 435px;"><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Who is likely going in to a market? Choices:  A: stress B: food C: that you D: spending money E: walking<n>Output:		A<n>```<n><n>### Partition:<n>*Partition by the age range:<n> *Ages: 10 to 16 and 17 to 23<n> *The mean age in the first age group is: 17 years old<n> *The number of people in the first age group: 16<n><n> *The number of customers who age is between 24 to 33 is: 16 - 16  = 0<n> *The mean of the second age group is: 24.23<n> *The number of person who age are between 24 to33: 16 + 0 = 16<n><n>*Partition by Gender:<n> <n> *The total number of Male and Female students is: 26<n> *The number of male students is: 13<n><n> <n> *The number of female students is: 14<n>```<n><n>```<n>### Find The Mode<n><n>*Find mode of 7 15 9 16 25 24<n>Output: 15<n>```<n><n>``` <n>---<n># DataFrame(Data, Column names, Row names)<n>```<n>

Use the method `collect()` in the `Arrays` class.](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/Arrays.html#collect-java.util.stream.Collector-java.util.function.Supplier-)<n><n>###### Notes<n><n>You must use `SortedSet` and `LinkedHashSet` in your code because both input ArrayLists do not have to be sorted while the returned collection must have the added items in sorted order. <n><n>###### Output:<n>Input:<n>ArrayList[1, 2, 3]<n>ArrayList[4, 5, 6]<n><n>Output:<n>LinkedHashSet[1, 2]<n>LinkedHashSet [3, 4, 5]<n><n>###### Approach:<n><n>```java<n>import java.util.Arrays;<n>import java.util.*;<n><n>public class combination {<n>    public static void main(String [] args){<n>        LinkedHashSet<Integer> firstSet = new LinkedHashSet<>();<n>        firstSet.add(1);<n>        firstSet.Add(2);<n>        firstSet = new LinkedHashMap<>();<n>        <n>        LinkedHashSet secondSet = new LinkedHasher();<n>        secondSet.add(4);<n>        secondSet.add(5);<n>        secondSet.ADD(6);<n>        <n>        //using Array and the collector class<n>        ArrayList<Integer> setOne = new ArrayList<Integer>();<n>        setOne.add(1);   setOne.add(2);   setOne.Add(3);<n>        <n>        ArrayList<Integer>:: setTwo = new ArrayList<Integer>::>    <n>        setTwo.add(4);   SetTwo.add(5);   SetTwo.Add(6);<n>         //using two collection and collectors to merge<n>        <n><n>        LinkedHashSet[] s=new LinkedHashSet[2];<n>        s

What is the price of a female horse?<n>Output: <n>$128<n><n>#################Code<n><n>def solution(i,j,k):<n><n>    b=i*j<n>    c=i*j*k<n>    d=j*k<n>    if((k-1)*(1+k/2)>0) and ((b-1)*(2/3)*(1+2/3)>0) and ((c-1)*(1/2)-4*(1/2)>0) :<n>       if((b-1)*(1-k/j)>0) and ((1/2)-j*(3/2)>0)  :<n>    return (3/2)*(5/2)*(k-1)<n>    <n>    <n><n>print (solution(2.5,2.5,123.5))<n><n>##########<n><n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. Choices:  A: restaurant B: basement C: all buildings D: carpet E: synagogue<n>Output:		E Answer explanation: "You don't mop Jewish floors." (Hebrew expression meaning "it's too clean.") A, B and C are all incorrect and are based on the meaning of the first word (“Holy”) in English. To confirm: a restaurant wouldn't be a holy building, but it needs a clean floor. A basement wouldn't be a Jewish building, and its floor would need cleaning. “All buildings” would be appropriate if the floors were cleaned only at holy times. Answers: E<n><n>Input: A family of six people rents a two-bedroom apartment in a major city. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:A blowfish lives free. He lives on his own. Where does he live? Choices:  A: fish market B: pet shop C: great outdoors D: river E: little mermaid<n>Output:		B<n><n>Input: There are an even number of trees in the forest. How many trees are there in all? Choices: A: 47 B: 53 C: 55 D: 59 E: 61<n>Output: A<n><n>### Solution 1:<n>```<n>a = 0<n>for i in range(int(input())):<n>    a += i<n>print(a)<n>```<n><n>### Solution2:<n>```<n>total_age = int(input())-20   <n>age_difference = 20<n>total_age = total_age-20<n>for i in total_age:<n>    a += age_difference<n>    age_difference += 20<n>    break<n>print(a) <n>```<n><n>## Result<n>output= 128<n>

Basically in every recursive call you get the total and a `sumOfPrices` value that denotes how much the total value is divided by the amount of candy in the cart. Once the `sumOfPrices`' values reaches 1 we stop the recursion call with the total.<n><n>\begin{code}<n>#include <iostream><n>#include <algorithm><n>#include <vector><n>#include <functional><n>#include <math.h><n>#include <utility><n><n>using namespace std;<n><n>int main()<n>{<n>    int a=0;<n>    int b=0;<n><n>    cout<<"Input: The difference in  ages between Richard and Hurly is 20. " << endl;<n>    cout<<"If Hurley is 15 years old, what are there combined ages on " << endl;<n><n>    cout << "30 years from now. ";<n>    cin >> b;<n><n>    cout>>a+a+b>>b-a;<n><n>    return 0;//not reached<n>}<n>\end{code}<n><n>Answer: Here is my take<n><n>\begin{blockquote}<n>Input: The difference<n>in ages between Richard and Hurry is 20..  If Hurry is 14 years<n>old, what are there combined age 40 years from today?<n><n>Output: 1000<n><n>Input: Pablo's mother agrees to<n>pay him one cent for every paper he reads...He plans to save the<n>money for some candy.Pablo always check out books that are exactly<n>150 pages..  After reading his book he went to the store  and bought<n>$15 worth of cider..and had $3 left over..How many books did<n>Pablo  read?<n><n>Output:7<n><n>Input:  A group of six friends plan to buy<n>a car. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:What is a place where you usually store dishes but not books? Choices:  A: apartment B: pantry C: table D: living room E: shelf<n>Output:		 A<n><n>Input: What is a place where you store books? Choices: A: pantry B: shelf C: apartment D: table E: living room<n>Output:  B<n><n>### Solution<n><n>#### Part - 1<n><n>```java<n>    int number=13,remainder=0;<n>    for(int i=1;i<=40;i++){//for first 40 loop<n>       remainder=number%10;<n>       number= number/10;<n>       if(remainder==20){<n>           break;<n>       } else {<n>           number= number+33;<n>       }<n>    }<n>    System.out.println(number);<n>```<n>#### Part - 2<n>```java<n>    public class My_class{<n>        public static void main(String[] args){<n>            int[] books = {16,  7, 10,  3,2,  0};<n>            int[] candy = {32, 6,  5,  27, 24};<n>            int[] cost = {301,286,257,134, 647};<n>            <n>            int sum=0;<n>            for(int i=0;i<=books.length;i++){<n>            for(int j=0;j<=candy.length;j++){<n>                for(int k=0;k<=cost.length;k++){<n>                            sum = sum+books[i]*candy[j]*cost[k];<n>                }<n>            } <n>            }<n>            System.out.println("C = " + sum);<n>        }}<n>```<n><n><n>### Solution Part - 2<n><n><n><n><n><n># [Instruction](https://dashboard.cybermoon.in#/challenges/d3c41c3c-f1fb-454b-bdbc-4e9df21d3d07/instructions):<n><n><n>```java<n>public class Solution{<n>public class Test{<n>    public static void main( String[] args){<n>    int k=0,n=0,q=0,numofk=0;<n>    Scanner s= new Scanner(System.in);<n>   
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Illegitimate designer handbags will not have a certificate of what? Choices:  A: actions B: legal C: authentic D: logical E: legitimate<n>Output:		B - legal<n><n># Solution:<n><n># I.  (Diff, Add)<n># -----<n># (A) If Hurley is 24 and Richard is 20, then 20 years later, Hurley will be 44, and Richard will be 40, so combined ages 40 later will be (24 + 24) = 48.<n><n># II. (Diff, Div)<n># ------<n># (D)<n># Divide 150 by 15 and the remainder will be 2.<n># Sum the remainders and the remainder will be B = 2 + 2 + 2 <n># B = 6 + 2 = 8<n><n># III. If the combined ages of two people X years from now are equal to the sum of their current ages, and that sum is Z, and B is their difference, then:<n># X = Z - 2(B) (I)<n># X = Z + 2<n># ((1) - 2(Z - 2(B))) - (2 - 2)<n># 1 - 2(Z) - 2<n><n># X = 31-2(32) - 2<n># = 32 - 8<n># = 24<n><n># IV. If the difference, A,between two numbers is 18, A2 and A3 are these numbers.<n># B = A + 3<n># C = A + 6<n># D=A + 12<n># If you were to add up B, C, and D, you would get the original number.<n># 18 + 18 + 36 = 62<n><n># V. Let A be a number. A is one more than the maximum 2-digit number that has the sum of 11. If A is 127, it can be rewritten as:<n># 10x10 + 7 or as:<n># 8x1 + 8<n># Thus if (10x10) is the A’s digit, and (8x1) is the B’s digit, then we could also write this number as:<n># (8A - B)<n># ------ <n><n># VI. If someone

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. I had a really bad time in a period but my friends helped me and I am very thankful to them.<n><n>There is some people, who are very caring and kindhearted. They have a pure heart, an innocent nature, a happy life and they always find a way to solve their problems and help other people in the time of their needs. <n>But there are also some people who are rude, selfish, impatient and unfortunate. They are always in trouble and have some worries.<n>They also face many problems in their life like losing respect, facing criticism, having doubts about their own capabilities, some suffer from depression also.<n>In my opinion, if you face trouble or get frustrated, instead of focusing on it, forget it,  move forward. Always forgive others, always stay calm and think on how to come over these situations

Choices: A: a woman B: a cashier C: a pregnant woman D: an employee with a tie E: the first person who walks in<n>Output: A<n>  <n>### Explanations of the input:<n><n><n><n>### Solution<n><n>Input:<n><n>Output: 168<n><n>```py<n>answer1 = 14 + 40/2 <n>answer2 = 133/3 - 150<n>answer3 = 1236 - 40/2 + 133 -150 + 3 - 500 = 126 -(1598 -140 ) = 126 -48 = 76<n>answer4 = 118 if A(118) else 309 else A(309)<n><n>answer1 = 20 + 38-20<n>```<n><n>### Result<n><n><n>```py<n>[A(14+40/2), A(133/3-150), A(1236-40/2+133-150+3-500 = 76), A(118 if A[118] else 309)]<n>    <n><n>import math<n><n>def A(x):<n>        if x <= 0:<n>                return "IMPOSSIBLE, HURLEY CAN'T GET THAT OLD"<n>        y = x / 2<n>        return 168<n>        <n>    <n>num_dict = {'A':A;}<n>    <n>print(num_dict)<n>```<n><n>## Hint 7:<n><n>* https://docs.python.org/3/howto/writing_python_unit_tests.html<n>* https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/wiki/Fixtures<n>

Choices:  A: wall B: office C: space shuttle D: front door E: tent<n>Output:		 T: office<n><n>---<n><n>input:<n>---<n><n>```<n>def foo ( ) :<n>    print ("Hello, World!")<n>```<n><n>output:<n>```<n>Hello, World!<n>Hello, World! Hello, World!<n>```<n><n>### Input : <n><n>* The only input to functions is the call itself. Functions don't have any input values. They work with arguments passed to them by the caller.<n><n>* When a program is compiled, only one method called constructor is executed.<n><n>* Functions return a single value as the result to the caller.<n><n>### Output : <n><n>* When the executable contains a return statement, it returns control immediately to the caller program for further processing.<n><n>* For a program that does not contain return, the control will go back to the nearest executable code that is not a return statement.<n><n>* For function calls, the calling program calls a function of the called program. Execution of the function returns to the calling program.<n><n>### C# has the following properties:<n><n>* It has syntax similar to that of C and Java.<n><n>* It provides classes and objects. It has a class library with built-in operators and data types.<n><n>* It is an Object-Oriented language. It has built-in exception handling.<n><n>* It does not allow you to put a semicolon at the end of each statement. It is case-sensitive.<n><n>--- <n><n>- It is imperative with OOPs features.<n>- It is a statically Typed<n>- It is an interpreted language.<n>- It does not support automatic types as well as garbage collection.<n>- It supports recursion as well as the use of closures and lambda expressions<n>- Supports Functions as well as First Class and higher Order Functions.<n> <n>### Exclusive:<n><n>- It has an unified set of rules.<n>- It supports OOPS concepts.<n>- It has an interactive approach to programming.<n>- It allows data abstraction to avoid duplication of code as well as to promote re-use and maintainability.<n>- It provides a robust set of operators.<n>- It has good support for large applications with performance issues.<n>- It supports inheritance.<n>- It does require compilation.<n>- It has a well written specification.<n>- It has support for many platforms

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Why would I want to be exercising? Choices:  A: fatigue B: relaxation C: tiredness D: muscle weakness E: losing weight<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input:What are the ingredients that can be used to make pizza? Choices:  cheese B: tomato sauce C: pepperoni D: spinach E: sardines<n>Output: D<n><n>Input:Which animal is better to have as a pet? Choices:  a duck B: a turtle C: goldfish D: iguana E: mouse<n>Output:E<n><n>Input:If the price of milk is $3.24, and there are 200 cents missing, what is the total price of milk? Choices: 200 c D: 204.24 E: 202.76 D: $5.24<n><n>Answer:<n>```<n>a)Richard’s current age <n>= (20 ‒ Hurley’s current age)<n>The difference in their ages after 40 years <n>= (Hurley’s current age + Richard’s current age) <n>– (Hurley’ age + Richard’ age))<n><n>⇒ <n>Hurley’s age after 40 years<n>= 14 + 12 ‒ 16 + 12<n>= 14 ‒ 6<n>= 8<n>Richard’ age after 40 <n>= 128 – 8 = 120<n><n>So, their combined age <n>= 140 years after 40 years.<n><n>b) After reading, he bought 150 cents worth of candy and has 3 cents<n>left over.<n>From the book, he earns $150 cents and<n>spent $88 cents.<n>So the amount he earned is = 150 ‒ 88<n>= $62<n><n>Total cost was $1700 – (62 + 88) <n>= $1630.<n><n>c) Since Brad is not participating in the car,<n>the total cost is = total cost(1 person) * 5 <n>= 900 dollars.<n><n>d) The correct answer is E.<n><n>e) The correct answer is B.<n>```<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane? Choices:  A: crash B: living C: slow down D: carry people E: speed up<n>Output:		B<n><n>Input: If 6n^2 = 108, what is the value of n?<n>Output: 9<n><n>Input: How many 6-foot high fences are required to fence in a rectangular area whose perimeter measures 144?<n>Output: 3 fences<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the two questions below.<n><n> <n> <n><details><summary style="float:right">Solution 1</summary><div style="width: 80%;border: 1px solid;padding: 15px; background : light blue;color: whitesmoke"><n>This is the solution for the above question.<n></div></details>  <n>Solution 1: Richard: 40<n>Hurley: 14<n>If Hurley is 15 years old, Hurley + Richard's combined ages will be 64  when Hurley is 26 years old. Since Richard is 4 years older than Hurley, subtract 4 from 26, Richard's combined ages when Hurley is 40 years old will be 22. <n><n> <n>  <details><summary style="color:red;background:cyan"><i>Solution 2</i></summary><div style="color:red"><n>This is the detailed solution for the above question and is a little more complex.<n></div></Details><n>Solution 2 :<n><n>```python<n>import math<n><n>In [1]: def main(pablo,money,h,candy):<n>            return h*money+candy<n><n>In [2]: pablo = 2<n><n>In [3]: pablo * 4<n>Out[2]: 8<n><n>In [4]: h * 4<n>Out [4]: 16<n><n>In [5]: main(pablo,4,2,3)<n>Out [5]: 12<n>```<n><n>So Pablo has to read 16 pages.<n><n> <n><n>### Instructions: Answer one of the questions below.<n><n><details><summary>Choose the answer to the following question:</summary><div class="qs"><p>Which of the following is a primary purpose of a computer program? Choices: A: to provide entertainment B: to help the

What is the rent?<n>Output: $100<n><n>Input: A jar contains 9 blue marbles, 8 green marbles, 7 red marbles, and 6 purple marbles. If 3 marbles are drawn from the jar, what is the probability of drawing a red one?<n>Output: 6/50<n><n>## Python Solution<n>```python<n>def problem_1():<n>    input_str = 'The difference in ages between Richard <n>                and Hurley is 37. <n>                If Hurley is 8 years old, what are <n>                their combined ages 14 years into <n>                the future?' <n>                <n>    print(input_str)<n>    <n>def problem_2():<n>    input_line = 'Pablo’s mother agrees <n>                to pay him one cent <n>                for every page he reads <n>                He plans to save the <n>                money for candy. Pablo <n>                always checks books that <n>                are exactly 300 pages <n>                <n>    input_line +='After finishing his <n>                books, he went to <n>                the store and bought $20 <n>                worth of candy.'<n>                <n>    input = input_line.splitlines()[2]<n>    output = input.split()<n>    print('\nRead pages:'+ output[0])<n>    <n>    input_line_1 = input_line.replace('their combined ages 40 <n>    years into the future?', 'How many books did Pablo <n>    read?') #Change 'Their combined ages +14...' to 'How many books did...'<n><n>    input_line.replace(input_line_1)<n>    print(input)  <n>    <n>problem_2()<n>```

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Where is a business restaurant likely to be located? Choices:  A: town B: at hotel C: mall D: business sector E: yellow pages<n>Output:		A<n><n>### Solution:<n>### Answer<n>In order to solve this task, I have used brute force method that iterates through all the possibilities of solving the equation. Since there is no solution given in this task I have used 3 different cases<n><n>Case 1: First one is that there is no answer since the equation is undistuable<n><n>Case 2: Second one is the correct answer, the sum of the ages has a remainder of 5 and their ages can be represented by (40-20-14) which =5 and therefore, the sum should be 120<n><n>Case 3: The third case is invalid since the sum of the ages when subtracted from 40 has a remainder of 2 and their ages can only be represented by the number 12 which in turn is invalid<n>#### Note:<n>Some of us used trial and error methods to find the right answer. I have provided the methodology on how I solved this<n><n>### Brute force approach<n>#### Approach 1<n>First, I have used the brute force approach to solve the cases. Here is the code snippet I have used for this method<n><n>#### Approach 2<n>Second approach here is to use multiple cases to solve the question which is to solve the equation using the difference between their ages. Here is the code for the same.<n>```js<n>var age = 35 // Richard's age is<n>            | age = 25 // Hurley's age<n>            | yearsFromNow = 15;<n>            | solution = {yearsFromNow: {remainder: 0, yearsBetween: age}}<n>            | while(age + yearsFromNow!= 45){<n>            |   year = yearsFromNow - age<n>                        | remainder = year % 5<n>                        | age = year - remainder<n>                        | solution.yearsFromNow = solution.yearsFromOne()<n>                        | solution = {...solution,...solution.yearsFromOne()}<n>                        | }<n>```<n>---<n>Thank you for reading!!! Please feel free to contact me on LinkedIn or Twitter or you can mail me at  [anuj@mrskutty.com](anuj@mr.skutty.com)

The function should return the minimum.<n><n>Example<n><n>Input: {4,5,2}<n>Output: 2<n><n>## Explanation<n><n>The function should loop through the array and check which one is the smallest.<n><n># Code<n>```py<n>def minimum(num):<n>    s=num[0]<n>    for i in num:<n>        if i<s:<n>            s=i<n>        else:<n>            continue<n>    return s<n>```<n><n>## Hint<n><n>```<n>s=num[0] # this line will become s=num[0]; if i<s: then the loop will run forever<n>for i in num:<n>    if i<s: # if i is < than s<n>        s=i<n>        print("i is smaller");<n>```<n><n>## Part Three: (4 Questions)<n>```py<n>def average(nums):<n>    return sum(nums)/len(nums)<n>```<n><n>## Explanaton<n><n>The function takes a list of numbers and the function multiplies it by the length of nums and divides by the length.<n><n># Code Solution<n>```py<n>def nums_to_average(nums):<n>     return sum(nums) / len(nums

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Where could you see an advertisement while reading news? Choices:  A: television B: bus C: email D: web page E: la ville<n>Output:		E<n><n>### My Implementations<n><n>```python<n><n>#Program to solve question 1<n>def age(x,y):<n>  diff = x - y #find difference in two consecutive numbers<n>  c=365*(diff-1)<n>  <n>  return (1+c)<n><n>def main():<n>  print(age(68,69))<n>```<n>Input: The difference between the two numbers is 2 years; age 1+age 2.<n>Output: 186<n><n>```python<n>#Program to solve Question 2<n>def read(x,y): #Find the number of pages read for x amount of dollars.<n>  page=(x/150)<n>  p=(1+page)<n>  return p<n><n>#Program to Question 3<n>def share(x,y): <n>  #Define a variable to store the number of friends in the group<n>  n = 6<n>  # Calculating the car cost<n>  C = 1700<n>  # Divide the cost among the number of friends <n>  print(share)<n>  print(n*(200-n))<n>  return C<n><n>```<n>Input:  Share the cost of the car equally between 6 friends<n>Output: The cost of the car equals 1700. Each friend will pay 200$<n><n>```python<n>  #Program for Question 4<n>  def email(x,y):  <n>  <n>  print(email)<n>  return 1700-y<n><n>```<n>Input(email(3,5))<n>Output: email is: 2<n>```<n><n>```python<n>def programName(x):<n>  c = int(x)<n>  a = c/0.76<n>  return (c - a)<n>```<n>Program for Question 4.<n><n><n>### Note:<n>#I made this program to print the number of years for a given age. This was done be calculating the difference as a multiple of 365 for each number below 30. This resulted in a time complexity of O(n), since each time, a new value of x needs to be checked. <n>#I also used the modulus operator to ensure that the calculated value remained the same, 186, after doing division.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:If an animal is tired, what is it likely to do? Choices:  A: bite B: lie down C: keep alive D: need to eat E: go to sleep<n>Output:		A<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>1. Solution Code:<n>    `int subtractDigit(int digit1, int digit2) {<n>      int c = digit1 - digit2;<n>      if (c >= 0) {<n>        return digit1;<n>      } else {<n>        return c % 10;<n>      }<n>}<n>int addDigit(int digit, int newDigit) {<n>  int c = digit + newDigit;<n>  if (c >= 10) {<n>    return 0;<n>  } else {<n>    return c;<n>  }<n>}<n>int main() {<n>  <n>  int digitA, i, newDigitB, result;<n>  <n>  scanf("%d", &digitA);<n>  scanf("%f", &newDigitB); //this will return value of 0 to 1, if decimal value is greater than 1 then it will not get any new digit.<n>  <n>  //if the integer digit is greater than newdigit<n>  for (i = 0; i < 3; i++) {<n>    digit = digitA;<n>    result = subtractDigit(digit, newDigitB);<n>    if (result == 0) {<n>      return digit;<n>    }<n>  }<n>  //if the decimal value  of digitA is too much<n>  for (i=3; i<11; i++) {<n>    <n>    digit = result;<n>    digitA = i;<n>    newDigit = result;<n>    result = newDigitB;<n>    //result =newDigit; //if result is equal to 0 then this loop will stop, we can directly return now<n>    printf("%d\n", result);<n>  }<n>  return 0;<n>}<n>  <n>2. Input format :<n><n><img src="https://i.imgur.com/61BhXH9.png" width="40%" alt = "image" style="max-height: 700px;" /><n><n>Example:<n><n><img src = "https://i.imgur;com/lf4D5Uy.png"><n>```bash<n>  123456<n>  67<n>```<n>3. Explanation:<n><n>  As we have the option

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Where is basketball court likely to be outdoors? Choices:  A: high school gymnasium B: city C: park D: use E: los angeles<n>Output:		C<n><n>### Solution:This class was very basic and was easy for me to solve. However, the questions were repetitive and were essentially the same.<n><n>![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35427872/54524273-ff6e1180-3f09-11e9-9b0b-5a76e1c89684.png)<n><n># Class #08-<n>## Instruction:<n><n>Write a function to find the factorial value of a given integer. The function should be generalizable to any integer and should still return that integer's factorial value.<n><n><n>Here is an example of such a function:<n>function factorial(n){<n>        n = n || 0;<n>        return (typeof n === "number")? n : <n>          (typeof n === "string")? [+n] :<n>          (typeof n == "array")?<n>            n.reduce(function (acc, n) { acc[n] || (acc[n] = 0) }<n>                    , {}) || 0 : 0;<n>        }<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>factorial(n){<n>    var acc = [1];<n>    var product = 1;<n>    product *= acc[n];<n>    for(var t=1;t<n;t++){<n>        acc[t] = product<n>        product *= acc[t]<n>    }<n>    return  product;<n>}<n><n># Class #10 - <n>## Instruction: Write a program that checks the validity of a credit card. A valid credit card consists of a 12 digit number. These numbers are either numerical(0-9) or letters('A'-'Z', in which 'A' is 0).<n>## Example:<n>### Input: <n>### Output: <n>### Solution:<n>## Example:<n>var a = 10;<n>var b =12;<n>var count = 0;<n>var number = [];<n>var card = "490000003458461";<n>for (var i = a; i <= number.length; i++){<n>    if(card.charAt(

The second person can chose to keep or exchange hands with the third person.<n>- The third person has 3 cards. The third person can chose to keep, exchange or stay silent (does not exchange hands).<n>- The fourth person has 2 pairs of one cards each. The fourth person can chose to keep hands as is or trade out with the fifth person.<n>- The fifth person has 2 pairs and can chose to keep hands or trade hands with the fourth person.<n>- The sixth person can chose to keep cards or trade with any other player.<n>- Only 1 card can be traded at a time. <n><n>Output: The fifth person has 4 cards in their hand. The fifth person trades hands with the fourth person and gains 4 cards in the hand. Choices:  A: liberal B: heretical C: recalcitrant D: conservadox E: heretical<n>Output:		A, B, C, or D.<n><n>#!/bin/bash<n>#This bash script demonstrates the concept of a while or do while loop<n>#WARNING: this is not an accepted solution! It's just for conceptual learning, you have to solve it using if, elif and else ifs at most<n>count=2<n>answer=0<n>if [ $answer -ne 0 ]; then<n>    echo "You got it (with only two loops!)"<n>else<n>    count=1<n>    echo "You'll need to retry a few times"<n>    while [ $answer -ne "1" ]; do<n>        echo "I need a solution..."<n>        echo "Please enter a solution."<n>        read answer2<n>        total=$(( $(date +%s) - $(date -d@$(date -d@"$answer" " " -d`date -d@$( date -d 2 days))) / 1440 ))<n>        if [ $total -ge 1 ]; then<n>            echo "Sadly you failed"<n>            echo "Try again"<n>            echo "This time a solution must be different"<n>            sleep 1<n>            if [ $total -le 1 ]; then<n>                if [ $(date +%s - $(date -d 2 days + %s)) -ge 1 ] && [ $(date +%S) -gt 120 ] || [ $(date +%T) -ge 2400 ] ; then<n>                    echo "Oh! It's just 5 seconds! You are the winner!"<n>                    break<n>                elif [ $(date -d"@$(date -d 2 day " " +@$(date -s "TZ=America/New_York" -d 100 second) 2300) +%s) -ge 2500 ]; then<n>                    echo "$(date -s"America/New_YorK -d"@"$(date +%s - $time)+%S)$(date +%S)"<n>                    echo "You're the time-traveler!"<n>                    echo "To win the game you will need to stay under"<n>                else<n>                    $sleep $count<n>                    $if $time -ge $(date -d"@" $(date -d
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. Choices:  A: air B: water C: earth D: space shuttle E: tunnel<n>Output:		A<n><n>#Code<n><n>N = int(input())<n>A = (N//5)*N % 5<n>B = (N//10)*N % 10<n>C = N // 5<n>if C == 5:<n>    print('Oxygen is required')<n>elif (B/A) % 2 < 1:<n>    print('Air')<n>elif C == 10:<n>    print('Space shuttle')<n>elif (B//A)%2 == 0:<n>    print("Water")<n>elif A>5:<n>    print("Earth")<n>else:<n>    print("Some sort of tunnel\n")<n>print("Done")<n><n><n>#Note:<n><n><n>### Input<n>> The difference in ages between rick and Hurley is 50 years. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:If I have a vintage, decorative light source in my possession, what is it likely to be? Choices:  A: sun B: sky C: candle D: house E: lamp<n>Output:		I<n><n>Input:If the sun is rising, I should... A: eat dinner B: go to bed C: get dressed D: go to work E: get sunscreen <n><n>Output: get dressed<n><n>Input:There are a lot of people living in New Jersey. At least... Choices: A: 42<n>B: 45<n>C: 47<n>D: 50<n>E: 30<n>Output: 47<n><n>Input:A group of 30 people want to go to lunch, but the restaurant can only seat 24 at a time. When a group is that big, there usually isn’t one person that sits alone if they are willing to make dinner plans together. What is the probability that some people will sit alone?<n>Output: 7.5<n><n>Input: 6 women are talking about hair cuts to get. How many different combinations of hairstyles are possible after they decide how they are going to cut their hair?<n>Output: 6!<n><n>Input:If two lines cross at a 60 degree angle, what is the ratio of the cross angles? Choices: A: a to b<n>B: a to 70<n>C: a to 90<n>D: a to 30<n>E: a to d<n><n>Output: a to b<n><n>Input: 3 friends split a bill by getting the sum of each person’s bill and dividing by three. What is the best way to ensure that no one person is going to pay more than they should based on their bill.<n>Output: Have the friend with the lowest bill and the friend with the highest bill cancel out their bills with each other.<n>```<n><n>## Result<n><n>```<n>12 <n><n>```<n><n>```<n>```<n> <n><n>  I<n>```<n><n>```  <n><n><n><n>## Solution<n><n>```<n>1)<n><n>```<n><n>### Method 1<n><n>```<n><n>$$ \Delta{A} = 12+20 \\<n>\Rightarrow A={20} $$<n>$$ \implies H{U}R{L}{E}I{N}{E}={20} \\<n>\Leftrightarrow {200}=14+20 \\<n><n>\Rightarrow{200}{-14}={20} $$

They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:The movie had many a song and dance, it was a what? Choices:  A: bollywood B: record C: musical D: jukebox E: napster<n>Output:		A, "All the world is a stage".<n><n>#### Example 1:<n>"""<n>def combine_ages(left, right): <n>	if left < right + 10:<n>		return left + 30<n>	else:<n>		return [right, left + 20] + [left + 10]<n>	"""<n><n>expected answer: 128  <n>actual answer: 120<n><n>#### Example 2:<n>"""<n>p = 14<n>q = 65<n>m= lambda x: p+x/q<n> <n>ans = [m(150) for _ in range(150)]<n>actual answer: [146, 294]<n><n>#### Example 3:<n>"""<n>m = lambda x: (1700/6) + x <n>b=0<n>ans = m(6)<n><n>expected answer: [40]<n>actual answer: 5<n><n>#### Example 4:<n>"""<n>import sys<n>def a():<n>	sys.setrecursionlimit(10000)<n>	a,b = b, a<n>	print a, len(a)<n>	return b<n><n>actual answer: 0, 4<n><n>"""<n>### Conclusion:<n><n>

However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:What would you tell ali to do if he bumps into you when you are walking? Choices:  A: work hard B: slow down C: wear shoes D: sell products E: speed up<n>Output:		C<n><n>---<n><n>**Explanation:**In this problem, we're given the following equation<n>$p + q$ = $30$<n>and asked what should the sum of $p$ and $q$ be if $30 + p$ $= p + q$?<n>The simplest choice is to simply add the two together to get $50$, but that's not what we're asked<n>and so, the correct answer is $10$.<n><n>Next, we have<n>$p + q = x$<n>and we want to know $x + p = x$<n>The answer here is $p$.<n><n>Finally, we have:<n>$p + q + r = k$<n>and we want the sum of $k$ and $p$ which is $p + k$.<n><n>---<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the question in which you explain whether you agree or disagree with the answer given above. C.<n><n>In the third scenario, I would tell him to slow down. The correct answer is C.<n><n>---<n><n>

She said a "hat" was just that - one. A "hat" was just one item. A "hat" represented a singular item while a "head" represented multiple items that could all fit on top of each other and the hat. She always said you could keep wearing your hat, but you couldn't keep wearing the head your hat sits on. Her name is Deborah, not Debbie, and the name Deborah wasn't even supposed to be Deborah. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Where would you find a binder containing homework assignments? Choices:  A: backpack B: bookcase C: office supply store D: office E: class room<n>Output:		B<n><n>#### Task Specification:<n>Your job is to implement a recursive function that takes a list of integers and returns the result that you find in that list.<n>1)The function should return the element at the index that is the smallest index with a number in it which is greater than the sum of all the integers in the list.<n>2) If there are no such indices, the return value should be -1.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>The function will be used to print the least and greatest value from the range [1,100]<n><n>### Example Input and Output:<n><n> Input:1,2,3,4,5,6<n> Output: 5,6<n><n> Input:11,12,13<n> Output:-1,-1<n><n> Input:15,14,13,8,9,6<n> Output:9,15<n>#### Task Specification<n><n>Your job is to write a recursive function called `findMinRecursive` that takes in a number of parameters `(int value, int min, int max, int counter)`<n><n>The function iterates until the current value (at the start of each iteration) is less or equal to the last value in the previous iteration. If the current value is greater than the second parameter, it sets it to 1, and returns the value.<n><n>If the current value is not equal to the second parameter it sets it to 2, and increments the number of values passed into the function.<n><n>A value is passed to the function if the current value is more than the second parameter. If the current value equals or is less than the second parameter it does not pass the value to the function and instead saves the value that the counter is at as the number of values passed to the function.<n><n>If the function does <n><n>   (set current value less than second value) <n><n>   AND is greater than the counter than the value is passed to the<n>   function. If not, the count is incremented.<n><n>The counter also begins at 0 as it counts only the values that reach the second parameter.<n><n>If no values ever reach the second parameter the result would be -1.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If the 15th multiple is 13,059, what is the number? <n>Output: C<n>2735924<n><n>Input: For a school dance, the cost was $20 and the guys paid half as much as the girls. The girls would be more than 60% more expensive than the guys, but there was a discount of 35% on every ticket. If the total sum of money raised was $2,262.50, how many people of each gender attended the dance?<n>Output: 525<n><n>#include <bits/stdc++.h><n>using namespace std;<n><n>#define rep(i, a, b) for(int (i) = (a); (i) <= (b); (i)++)<n>#define rgen(g) for(__typeof((g).end()) (g).first == (g).second)<n>#define REP2(i, a, n) for (int (i) = a; (i) < n; (i)++)<n><n>const int mod = 1e9 + 7;<n>const int MAX_N = 10000 + 3;<n><n>int A, a, b, c, d;<n><n>int main() {<n>    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(false); cin.tie(0);<n>    cin >> A;<n>    a = 2 * A;<n>    rep(i, 0, A) {<n>        c = a / 2;<n>        d = mod - c;<n>        b = 1 + mod / d - 3 * 3 * (mod / d);<n>        a = c * (mod / 2);<n>    }<n><n>    //Output<n>    cout << b << '\n';<n><n>    return 0;<n>}

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: deadly B: dangerous C: unconcerned D: stressful E: harder when weather bad<n>Output:		A<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>* If Hurley is 4x + 1 and the difference 40 = 50x + 20, then 40 + 4x + 20 = 40 + 50x + x = 5x(x+10). Rearrange the equation to x2 – 10x + 40 = 0 (a quadratic function of x). Since the equation is quadratic and has only one solution, Hurley is 21 years old 40 years later.<n><n>* Pablo takes 150 pages books for 8 months and 4 months to finish the same number of books and so for 12 months. Pablo reads for a year and the total pages read is 1,950 pages. Let us round up to 2000 pages. To save for a candy Pablo collects $2 a week for reading for a year. The total number of weeks he read is 2000/50 pages/week = 40 weeks. So Pablo read for 40 weeks and after saving for the candy, he has $3 remaining. So the saving is for 100 weeks. But the number of pages read is 100 x 150 =25,000 pages. Then the average number of books read per week is 100 pages. The total number of books that Pablo has read is (25,00/100) = 250 books.<n><n>* Each of 6 friends has to pay $285. After Brad joined, each of the 6 friends pays $368. So the difference is $76 which is equal to $40/6. After Brad joins all of the friends must pay $110 each for the car.<n><n>* Answers that contains C, D, E & A have the least common factor, 2. The factor of 2 is given the lowest place and the highest place is the multiple of 2. D is the answer that has lowest common factor in both numerator and denominator.<n><n><n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: nice feeling B: good karma C: respect D: new freedom E: good heart<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input: Two men and a woman go hiking in the woods and they split a two-pound bag of trail mix. After they split it, the woman has a little more. Why?<n>Output: She has a little more.<n><n>1. What is a common approach developers sometimes adopt when they try to improve their code? <n><n>2. What is static analysis? <n><n>3. How can static analysis be used as part of a software development process? What problems can it help us to avoid? What problems can it solve without a large investment in resources? <n><n>4. A static analysis tool has been used to find bugs and recommend improvements to your project. What is the one thing you need to know to be able to act on that information to improve the quality, reliability and maintainability of your project? <n><n>5. What is a unit test? <n><n>6. What are some of the advantages a developer would have by adopting a process that uses static analysis and unit testing? <n>### Solving:<n>A. It can help you find and fix bugs before you release your code. It can help you maintain your code, which means improving your performance.<n><n>B. It can help you by avoiding mistakes and bugs. It can help you solve problems without wasting money or time, or by saving some money and time.<n><n>2. Static analysis is the process of analyzing the structure of software using a static analysis tool on its source code.<n><n><n><n>4. The one thing you need to do is make the changes recommended by the tool and follow the recommendations of the tool. <n><n>5. A unit test is a process of testing software to determine its integrity, and to determine what type of error it is (bug). <n><n>6. Using Static analysis saves you the process of going through every line of code to see if possible errors are there; also having unit testing can help you see if something you did was correct when testing it, without having to make the same test again and again. <n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Where would you find a bee gathering pollen? Choices:  A: united states B: sky C: court D: field of flowers E: orchard<n>Output:		none of the above<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>```<n>public class Solution {<n>    int getSum(int[] nums) {<n>        int sum = 0;<n>        int n = nums.length;<n><n>        Arrays.sort(nums);<n><n>        for (int i=n-1; i > -1; i--) {<n>            sum += nums[i];<n>            if (sum == 0) break;<n>        }<n>        return sum;<n>    }<n>    public static void main(String[] args) {<n>        Solution solution = new Solution();<n>        assert solution.solution(new int[] {1}) == 1;<n>        assert solution.getSum(new int[] {5, 7}) == 12;<n>    }<n>}<n>```

If Hurley is fourteen years old in the future, then their combined ages are then 108 years in the future.<n><n>Richard is 140 years away from Hurley's present age. If Richard is 4 years older than Hurley, then Richard's present age is 154. <n><n>Richard is now 158 after subtracting Hurley's present agae and Richard will be 204 after the future years and Richard is now 140 years ahead of Hurley.<n><n>Richard's age is now 144 years 204 times 20 is 5028. Hurley's present is 20 less than Richard, so he is now 164. <n><n>Now Richard and Hurley are 144 and 164 years away from the present. <n><n>The second part of the problem says how Pablo managed to save $15 for $15 worth of candies using 150 pages of books that he read. He read 10 pages for every fifty cents. So he read 10 books with 150 pages for $10 cents.<n><n>Pablo read 150 pages then he would earn $10 and have a dollar

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Where do I put my coffee mug after it's dry? Choices:  A: shelf B: desktop C: cabinet D: kitchen E: cupboard<n>Output:		B<n><n>## Solution:<n>We split a pizza into 6 equal pieces. So the order would be A,B,C,D,E. So A-6 is left with piece for B to take.<n><n>## Solution2:<n><n>We split a pizzas into 6 equal pieces, so A, B, C, D, E. And since there are 3 orders, there are 3 possibilities for distribution.<n><n>So all the possible solutions are<n>A,B,C<n>A,B,D<n>A,B,E<n>A,C,D<n>A,C,E<n>A,D,E<n>B,C,D<n>B,C,E<n>B,D,E<n>C,D,E<n>And the answer would be the case where A,B,C<n><n><n>## Solution3:<n><n>So there are 6 possible combinations for each question<n><n>Question(a):<n><n>Question(b):<n><n>Question(c):<n><n>Question(d):<n><n>Question(e) A,B<n><n>So, There will be 6 X 1 = 6 cases in a total of 6 possibilities for each question. Hence the total number of cases comes out to be 6 X 3 = 18
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. E: work<n>Output:		school building<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>ans=($(cat./answer.txt))# Read file<n>case $1 in<n><n>    A) <n>        if   [[ $ans == "A" ]];then echo "A";fi<n>        if   [[  $ans == "b" ]], then echo "b"; fi<n>        if   [[   $ans == "a" ]]  then echo "a"; fi<n>        if [[ $ans == "b,a" ]]  ;then echo "b,a"; fi<n>        echo "None of the above."<n><n>    )<n>    B) echo "b"<n>    C) echo "c"<n>    D) echo "d"<n>    E) if [[ $ans = E ]] ;then echo "E"; fi<n>    F ) echo "F"<n>    G ) echo "G"<n>    H) echo "h"<n>    I) echo "I"<n>    J) echo "j"<n>    K) echo "K"<n>    L) echo "L"<n>    M) echo "m"<n>    N) echo "n"<n>    O ) echo "O"<n>    P) echo "P"<n>    Q) echo "Q"<n>    R ) echo "R"<n>    S) echo "s"<n>    T) echo "T"<n>    U) echo "u"<n>    V ) echo "V"<n>    W) echo "W"<n>    X ) echo "x"<n>    Y) echo "Y"<n>    Z ) echo "Z"<n>    * )exit 0;exit 0;exit;exit 0<n><n><n>```<n>

If the oldest person is X and the youngest person is Y then their combined age after 40 years is 50 years now. So let's solve for X+Y<n>- X+Y = 20 + (y/4)<n>- X+Y= 50<n>	<n>- X = 40 - Y<n>	<n>- X= 40 - ((y/4))<n>		<n>	Hope this is helpful and it works for everyone. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. What is the combined age of the whole family?<n>Output: 31<n><n>### Solution<n><n>```<n>class Solution {<n>    public:<n>        int findMinWindowValue(string S, vector<string>& words) {<n>            auto cmp = [](string const& a, string const& b) {<n>                return a.length() < b.length();<n>            };<n>            <n>            size_t h = words.size();<n>            if (h == 0)<n>                return 0;<n>            int len = S.length();<n>            int wsize = 0;<n>            auto it = lower_bound(words.begin(), words.end(), S, cmp);<n>            <n>//            <n>            <n>            auto it2 = upper_bound(words.end(), S.end(), words.back(), cmp); <n>            <n>            vector<int> count(h+1, 0);<n>           <n>            for (int i = 0; i < h; i++)<n>                count[i] = find(words.begin(), it2, words[i]) - words.begin();<n>//            vector<string> pos;<n>//#pragma omp parallel for shared (it) private (s, e, m, s1, e1, wsize)<n>//            for (auto o: S ) {<n>//                string s1 = s.substr(o, o + 1);<n>//                char tmp = s[o];<n>//                s[i] = tmp;<n>//<n>//                int m = S.find(s1);<n>//<n>////                //pos<n>//                vector<string> tmp_pos(1);<n>//                if ( pos.size() < count[i] + 1) {<n>//                    pos.push_back(s.substr(tmp++, m - 1 + 1));<n>//                <n>//                    if (pos.back() == pos.front()) {<n>//                        pos[pos.size() - 1] = pos[pos.size( )- 1

However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Where would you hear a viola along side many other string and brass instruments? Choices:  A: symphony B: band C: create music D: orchestra E: string quartet<n>Output:		A<n><n>Input: I am always on the lookout for good value in everything I buy. So, I do not plan to buy the CD player, but only its component parts. I think of a computer, or a camera for instance, as really just a collection of electronic circuits combined with the physical parts they need to be housed in. These components, such as microchips, or memory chips, are already sold individually. I can build a computer from a kit that contains only the components I need. I find I can get much better value for my money this way. I do the same with stereo components like a CD player or speakers. When I want a CD player, I buy the unit itself, or the complete stereo component. If, on the other hand, I cannot find the complete components I need at a value that I consider reasonable, then I build my stereo component from its component parts. This way, I get exactly my desired system and I can save money and make them cheaper. Of course, this can be a lot of work - to make it easier, I will buy the pieces of the stereo I don't already have to complete my stereo system. But I will only buy the parts when I need them.<n><n>Output: 1<n><n>Input:Which of the answers below can be described as "the price charged to a customer for the goods and services made available through a given unit of the product in a given accounting period"?<n>Output: d) total revenue<n><n>Input: The question above refers to which of the following? a. revenue per unit b. total revenue c. price per unit d. total costs<n>Output:  b<n><n>Input: The expression "average price" can be used to denote which of the following?<n>Output: a) total price / total quantity<n><n>Input: Which of the statements below is true of costs incurred and payments made so far in the preparation of the statement of financial position?<n>Output: c) Costs and expenses are not included in the statement of financial position<n><n>Input: The following costs and expenses may show up on a company's statement of financial position at the end of an accounting period: <n><n>a) prepaid salary expense<n><n>b) deferred income<n><n>c) accrued liabilities<n><n>d) interest expense

They must play at least 3 rounds before making a decision. The loser must do chores. In every round, they draw and select their choice of rock, paper or scissors with one of the following methods:<n>1. They alternately pick one of the three options for each round.<n>2. They roll two dice. If the total of the dice is less than 11, they select rock. If the total is an odd number, they select paper. If the total is even, they select scissors.<n>3. They throw darts at a target. Each dart that lands in the target is added together. Choices:  A: car B: fuel system C: accelerate D: boat E: airplane<n>Output:		24<n><n>Input:A clown is going to drive a car in a clown parade. What should she drive in such a way that 100 clowns have less than 100 cents to get in the car? Choices: 1 2 3 4 24<n>Output:1<n><n>Incorrect answer:<n>```python<n><n>Input:The difference in ages between Richard Nixon and Hurley Smith is 20. if Hurley was 14 years old what were their combined ages 4 years from now? output:<n><n>40<n>difference = 4 - 4 = 0<n>```<n><n>Correct Code:<n>```python<n>def sum_ages(b,c):<n>    b_age = -b <n>    c_age = -c <n>    age_combined = (b_age-c_age) - (b_age+c_age)<n>    return age_combined<n>```<n><n>### Instruction:Complete the for loop.<n><n>Input: A clown is going for a car ride in a clown car. What would be the best way to get a clown from 100 cows to enter a car with only 100 cots? Choices: 4 11<n>Output:4<n><n>Input: A boy wanted to add 4 numbers and he got the answer 87. But when he multiplies the same 4 answer by the same multiplier he get 160. What did he get? Output:4<n><n><n>Incorrect Code: <n>```python<n>b=0<n>c=0<n>while b<100:<n>    while c<100: print(b*c)<n>    b+=1<n>    c+=1<n><n>```<n><n>Corresponding Code:<n><n>```python<n>b+=1<n>c+=1<n>while c<100 - 1:<n>    print(b*c + b)<n>    b+= 1<n>```

Hurley will be 14 years old in 26 years and 20 years from now, they are combined ages will be 66.<n><n>The first 150 books is 15 pages.<n>The remaining 135 books is 1155 pages and 15 pages. So one cent for one reading of 150 pages plus 1155 times 15 pages is $115.5. Since $15 buys the total $115.6 and $3 is left over, $3 is 0.3%. 0.3% of $115.8 is $0.35. 0.35 of Pablo's $115.9 book count is 0.85 times 4 leaves 3.15 pages.<n><n>Since $500 is taken out for the car wash and the remaining cost is $1200, $6 * 6 = $36 is left over.<n><n>### Question 1<n><n>1. What would be the result if we take the age of the current king from Richard and put it in Hurley? The answer is the current king's age, in this case 24.<n>2. Richard is 36 and Hurley will be 24 in 20 years.<n>3. There will be 40 years between them, Richard will be 96 in 40 years and Hurley will be age 20. The total combined age is 120 years.<n>4. If the combined age is 14 years and Hurley is 12 years, the total is 40 years.<n><n>### Step 1<n><n>1) Find the current king is 36 at present time and the next King will be 24 if it is divided between both. The answer as it is the current king' age. King is 36.<n><n>### HW01<n><n>- [Back](./../HW01.md)<n>- [Next](./../HW11.md)<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. Choices:  A: injury B: death C: playing uno D: coma E: falling down<n>Output:		Injury <n>Sky diving isn't for everyone, but this isn't your typical dive either. Every time a person jumps out of a plane, they have a 16 out of a 100 chance of dying. For every 25 jumps, one person will die. That is approximately a 1.6% mortality rate. These statistics are based on the amount of people who have ever jumped out of a plane. These individuals who made 100 successful jumps have a 1 in 1000 chance of dying, 0.1% in fact. These numbers have nothing to do with the safety of the sky diving operator or the conditions.<n><n>Input: How many liters of gas does a car need to travel 600 kilometers when it gets 20 kilometers per liter?<n>Output: 30 liters<n><n>Input: The distance from Portland, Oregon to Miami, Florida is 2774 miles. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:If you did well on the test, you might get an A as a what? Choices:  A: see work B: practice C: quiz D: school grade E: homework<n>Output:		A: see work<n><n>Input:Your mom gave you $12.50 for dinner last night. This morning, she asked if you had enough for breakfast, and you told her $2.45. You gave your mom $11.50 for breakfast. How much money does your mom have left?<n>Output: $13.75<n><n>Input:There was an event at your school where everyone at the school was buying tickets to a drawing. If you bought 4 tickets, each for $1, and you sold them to your friends. You sold 2 tickets to one friend for $2 each, another ticket to another friend for $3, and sold 3 tickets to the last person who attended school for $1. If your friend told you that they also bought 4 tickets themselves, how much money did the school make if all 15 tickets were sold?<n>Output: $90<n><n>Input:There is an auction to see who would sell their car last. You sold your car for $2000, but the winner of the auction sold his car for $3500. Why did you have a lower price than the winner?<n>Output: Because I lost<n><n>Input: You go to the gas station where it is $4/ gallon of gasoline. You fill up the tank for the car after getting gas and drive exactly 150 miles one way. How much did you spend on gas to fill up the entire tank? (You can always fill up the tank on the way back.)<n>Output: $120<n><n>Input: How much money did each person contribute to the party? If it was $125 total and 4 people participated, how much money would each person have to pay?<n>Output: 31<n><n>Input: You were on the waiting list to get the game, and when it came out, it was sold out immediately. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: 40<n><n>Input:Where is a fox likely to be caught? Choices:  A: tennessee B: inside joke C: grassy field D: the forrest E: england<n>Output:		C: the fox is likely to be found in a grassy field<n><n>Input: What is the capital of Canada? Choices: A: mexico B: washington C: montreal D: montreal<n>Output: A: Canada's capital is Mexico<n><n>Input: What are the first three prime numbers?<n>Output: 3<n><n><n>## [Solution]<n><n>### Code<n><n>```<n>---<n>code:<n>  interval:<n>    - end: 2020-10-01<n>  language: python3<n>---<n><n>solution.py:<n>```<n>class Solution:<n>    def threeSum(self, nums):<n>        nums= sorted(nums)<n>        nums.extend([nums[0],nums[0]+1,nums[0]+2])<n><n>        def get_interval(idx,arr):<n>            low, high=arr[0:idx],arr[idx]<n>            mid=low+int((high-low)/2)<n>            #print("low,high: ",low,high," mid: ",mid)<n>            return (low,high,mid) if nums[mid]==0 else get_interval(idx+1,arr)<n><n>        return get_interval(0,nums)<n>```<n><n>### Time Complexity: O(nlogn)<n><n>### Space Complexity: O(1)<n><n>### Explain<n><n>1. The function is given an array of numbers and returns an array of three numbers that sum to zero, if possible.<n><n>2. We begin with the set of all possible combinations s(i)=(first + i, last + i).<n><n>3. We perform a dp on the set.<n><n>a. If s(0).sum=2k: if s(1).sum=k+1. If (k+1)< last: s(1)=(first,k+1). If last=k+1: s(1)=[first,k+1]. If k==0: s(1)=[(first,last+1)] If k==last: last=last-1 Then, all(s(i-1).l)==(last+1, last+2)<n><n>4. We store the number of such values in the set.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally.
